Module chav1961.purelib
Package chav1961.purelib.basic.interfaces

Interface LoggerFacade

All Superinterfaces:
java.lang.AutoCloseable, java.io.Closeable
All Known Implementing Classes:
AbstractLoggerFacade, DefaultLoggerFacade, JStateString, LocalizableLoggerWrapper, NullLoggerFacade, PureLogger, StandardJRELoggerFacade, SystemErrLoggerFacade
public interface LoggerFacade
extends java.io.Closeable

This interface is a facade for different loggers. The great problem with loggers is a huge amount of them at now. This Zoo strongly reduces compatibility of the 3-rd party software in the large systems. This interface isolates the pure library software from depending of any loggers. All the classes in this library use the interface as the only way to get access to loggers. The next serious problem with loggers is is an extra-large amount of the logging trace in the large system logs. Most of all the trace doesn't have usability in the normal modes, but make by developers for the "post-fly-analyze" purpose only. As a result, there are two typical problems with the log:

  • the log information is too small - can't make adequate analysis
  • the log information is too large - can't make adequate analysis too

The solving of this problem, IMHO, is a transaction logging mode. When you start any action can be aborted or failed, you start logging in the transaction logger. If the actions ends successfully, you can rollback the trace, and the logging trace is simply rejected without storing it to log files. If transaction was aborted or failed, you get all logger trace, which will be stored in the log files.

To reduce amount of the stack trace lines (when exceptions are logged), this logger supports a set of reducing algorithms. They are defined by LoggerFacade.Reducing enumeration and means:

  • reduceJREPath - exclude any stack trace lines with java.*, javax.*, sun.* packages
  • reduceOverSubtree - exclude any stack trace lines, located inside the current package and it's sub-packages. Valid in the transaction mode only
  • reduceRuntimeExceptions - excludes any stack trace for RuntimeException and it's children, if is throws at the same program code location again
  • reduceCause - if the exception contains 'cause', print stack trace only for it
  • reduceTrace - exclude stack trace fully, remains the exception messages only

The most of all methods of this interface return LoggerFacade type. This is exactly a 'this' reference, so you can use this interface in the chained calls (for example MyLogger.message(Severity.info,"message1").message(Severity.warning,"message2")).

The logger facade interface implementation not needs to be thread-safe

Since:
0.0.1
Author:
Alexander Chernomyrdin aka chav1961

    • transaction

      LoggerFacade transaction​(java.lang.String mark) throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException

      Create transaction logger instance. Use this call in the try-with-resource statement! Any messages to transaction logger will not be send anywhere before transaction end. Real transferring will be initiated when close() method would be called. Calling rollback() method immediately before calling close() scratches all messages from the transaction logger. This functionality is designed especially for reducing logger output: successful ending of the transaction doesn't produce any messages, but fatal ending keeps detailed trace for the longer analysis:

      try(LoggerFacade logger = ...transaction("MyTransaction")) {
      . . .
         logger.message(...);
      . . .
         logger.rollback(); // scratch all logger content on successful ending
      }
       For performance reason, method transaction(String, Class) is more preferred to use.
      Parameters:
      mark - any string to mark transaction logger trace for identification purposes. Can't be null or empty
      Returns:
      new logger instance. It must be closed mandatory
      Throws:
      java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - when mark string is null or empty

    • transaction

      LoggerFacade transaction​(java.lang.String mark, java.lang.Class<?> root) throws java.lang.NullPointerException, java.lang.IllegalArgumentException

      Create transaction logger instance. Use this call in the try-with-resource statement! Any messages to transaction logger will not be send anywhere before transaction end. Real transferring will be initiated when close() method would be called. Calling rollback() method immediately before calling close() scratches all messages from the transaction logger. This functionality is designed especially for reducing logger output: successful ending of the transaction doesn't produce any messages, but fatal ending keeps detailed trace for the longer analysis:

      try(LoggerFacade logger = ...transaction("MyTransaction")) {
      . . .
         logger.message(...);
      . . .
         logger.rollback(); // scratch all logger content on successful ending
      }
      Parameters:
      mark - any string to mark transaction logger trace for identification purposes
      root - root class where transaction logger was created
      Returns:
      new logger instance. It must be closed mandatory
      Throws:
      java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - when mark string is null or empty
      java.lang.NullPointerException - when root class is null

    • rollback

      void rollback()

      Rollback transaction trace. If the logger instance is not a transaction logger, this call has no effect. Use this method as the last call in the try-with-resource block body!

      See Also:
      transaction(String)

    • close

      void close()

      Close logger. If this logger is transaction logger and it has any trace, the trace will be sent to the log file. To avoid this, use rollback() call in the try-with-resource block body.

      Specified by:
      close in interface java.lang.AutoCloseable
      Specified by:
      close in interface java.io.Closeable
      See Also:
      transaction(String)
